title: The Law of Least Effort
summary: Human behavior follows the Law of Least Effort: we naturally gravitate toward the option that requires the least amount of work. To build good habits, reduce the friction associated with them. To break bad habits, increase the friction. Make it easy to do the right thing and hard to do the wrong thing.
keyIdeas: We naturally choose the path of least resistance.
Reduce friction to make good habits easier.
Increase friction to make bad habits harder.
Environment design can make or break a habit.
The less energy a habit requires, the more likely it is to occur.
Prime your environment to make good habits effortless.
Small reductions in friction can lead to significant behavior changes.
examples: Prepare your gym bag the night before to reduce morning friction.
Unplug your TV and put the remote in another room to reduce watching.
Keep healthy snacks at eye level and unhealthy ones out of sight.
exercises: Identify one way to reduce friction for a good habit.
Add one step of friction to make a bad habit harder.
Redesign one aspect of your environment to follow the Law of Least Effort.
reflections: What friction is preventing you from performing your desired habits?
How can you make your environment work with human nature instead of against it?
